He told the Liverpool Echo that the Bank wants to see unemployment come down around the country and be assured an recovery has broadened out beyond the south-east. He tells the Yorkshire Post that there is a “pick-up of growth” in Europe and “the United States is continuing to perform well” and that “within the UK, we are probably leading the pack of the major advanced economies as we speak right now.” • We will be watching events in Italy where politicial uncertainty pushed stock markets lower on Thursday • Attention in global financial markets is very much on the US as it nears a debt ceiling showdown • In Berlin, Germany’s SPD party holds a meeting of leaders to decide whether to enter a coalition with Angela Merkel’s CDU • Back in the UK, the government has just announced the Royal Mail is to be valued at between £2.6bn and £3.3bn We will bring you details on all of those as well as breaking financial news throughout the day …

webTitle: Debt standoff could 'all but wipe out' US recovery, economists warn

fields.bodyText: Washington's increasingly heated battle over raising the US debt limit could all but wipe out the country's fragile recovery, economists warned on Friday. The row over raising the government's $16.7tn borrowing limit is much more serious than the separate but politically linked tussles over the federal government's spending authority, which could trigged a government shutdown if they are not resolved by Monday. While the shutdown would rattle the economy, economists said it would be nothing compared to a failure to raise the US's debt ceiling. Treasury secretary Jack Lew warned Congress this week that unless it imminently approves an increase in the borrowing limit, the US government will be unable to meet its bills by 17 October. But Barack Obama is refusing to bow to Republican demands that he defund his landmark healthcare reforms in return for an agreement. "Even if Congress can reach an agreement to renew the federal government's spending authority before it expires this Monday – which is looking increasingly unlikely – there's a much more serious battle brewing over the push to raise the debt ceiling before the Treasury runs out of money sometime shortly after 17 October," Capital Economics pair Paul Ashworth and Paul Dales wrote to clients Friday. "We have no idea exactly how this standoff will be resolved, and even less of an idea exactly when any agreement might be reached. But, at this stage, we would be lying if we said we were confident of a positive outcome." The Bureau of Labor Statistics will release its latest jobs report next Friday and important manufacturing data will also be released next week. In both cases, economists expect the figures to underline the strengthening US economy. But PNC bank senior macroeconomist Gus Faucher said a failure to raise the debt ceiling would "all but wipe out" that recovery. "There will be an immediate drag on the economy, interest rates will rise for everyone. Social security, federal wages and contracts will not get paid. It would be disastrous," he said. "The economy would basically stall." The chances of a shutdown appeared roughly 50-50 on Friday morning as the Senate prepared to send the budget legislation back to the House of Representatives without the controversial clause that would defund Obamacare. A vote was due on a Senate procedural measure known as cloture, which will provide a key test of Republican support for a protracted fight. In theory, Republicans have enough senators to block the cloture motion, which requires 60 votes to pass, but most GOP moderates have already declared they will not obstruct passage any further. This will allow Democrats to hold a simple majority vote on an amendment taking out the healthcare clause and stage a further vote on the revised bill later on Friday afternoon. House leaders then have until Monday night to vote in favour of the revised bill, known as a continuing resolution, or force a government shutdown by sending the it back to the Senate again with fresh demands that are unlikely to be met in time. It was still unclear on Friday morning how Republicans in the House will react, although they now have slightly more time to debate their response after a late-night deal to speed up the Senate timetable. Mark Zandi, the chief economist at Moody's Analytics and a former adviser to Republican presidential hopeful John McCain, testified in Congress this week that failure to reach an agreement would trigger "a severe recession". He told the joint economic committee: "If you don't do it in time, confidence will evaporate, consumer confidence will sharply decline. Businesses will stop hiring, consumers will stop spending, the stock market will fall significantly in value, borrowing costs for businesses and households will rise." In a letter released by the Treasury Department on Wednesday, Lew said that on 17 October, "Treasury would have only approximately $30bn to meet our country's commitments". He said the sum fell far short of the $60bn the US needs on some days to meet its obligations. "If we have insufficient cash on hand, it would be impossible for the United States of America to meet all of its obligations – for the first time in our history," said Lew.

webTitle: SSE in talks to scale back on wave and tidal power projects

fields.standfirst: Energy firm's move follows those by other investors, with lobby group blaming regulatory environment for depressed forecasts
fields.body:
Britain's leading role in the development of experimental marine and tidal technology was under threat on Friday as it emerged that SSE, one of the major investors, is talking to partners about scaling back its investment in key schemes.

The move follows similar ones by other major players and comes in the middle of a fractious debate about renewables and the future of the wider power market following Ed Miliband's promise to freeze energy prices and break up big power firms if Labour wins the 2015 election.

The lobby group that represents wave and tidal power said the difficult regulatory environment has depressed forecasts of how much capacity could be deployed and slowed the progress of the sector.

"Without a clear route to market and a coherent plan for attaining volume in the sector, the UK risks being overtaken in this global race for our next decade's most exciting low carbon market," said David Krohn, wave and tidal development manager at RenewableUK.

"Wave energy is still in the early years of its story and we need perspective and patience as our industry matures. It is never good when a major player pulls back, but context is important here.

"Wave developers are working hard to develop and refine the technology. To do this they need to have long-term support and volume. Wave array projects need to be in the water as soon as possible, not in five years' time, so we can get the learning done now."

SSE confirmed it was reconsidering its four major projects off the Orkney Islands and in the Pentland Firth off Scotland but denied it was pulling out. "We are reviewing our portfolio but we have not at this stage reached any conclusion," said a spokesman.

This followed a report in trade publication ReNews that the energy firm had told project partners it intended to withdraw from 800MW of wave and tidal arrays in the waters of the Pentland Firth and off the island of Orkney.

Other sources said they did not believe SSE would exit completely but the sector was very nervous following a scaling back by other big six players, RWE and E.ON.

The SSE website boasts that the UK has a large marine energy resource that can uses both wave and tidal power. "SSE aims to have several hundred megawatts of marine capacity operating or with consent by 2020 and is developing a number of options around the UK," it said.

On Friday, SSE's shares rose for the first time in three days following City sell-offs in the aftermath of the speech by Miliband. SSE's stock value rose 1% but that leaves it down 7% since Wednesday, the day after his Labour conference speech.

The European Marine Energy Centre in Orkney, set up with government money to provide testing facilities for smaller scale wave and tidal devices, said interest from around the world in its facilities was "still on the up".

webTitle: FTSE 100 hit by US debt worries but Centrica and SSE stablise after slump

fields.standfirst: Investors cautious ahead of possible American government shutdown and hints of no further UK QE
fields.body:
Energy companies suffered a jolt this week.

Centrica and SSE saw nearly £3bn wiped off their market value in the wake of Labour leader Ed Miliband unveiling a pledge to freeze gas and electricity prices for 20 months if the party wins the next election.

The policy, which infuriated the companies but could prove popular with voters, would cost them around £4.5bn. It sent their shares tumbling on Wednesday and Thursday, both on the pledge itself and the political risks the companies now face. But they both saw the selling stop on Friday, with Centrica edging up 0.1p to 367p while SSE, the former Scottish and Southern Energy, added 8p to £14.68.

Analysts at Credit Suisse said:

We need to see how proposals might work, and expect to hear more details over time. We think the industry needs to raise prices by around 10% in the coming four weeks, and delaying price rises will mean neither SSE nor Centrica can make consensus forecasts. This will be a key test for the stocks.
Centrica has a stated [residential profit] target of around £600m (within a £500m-£700m range), which it needs to make guidance of around 28p a share. It is possible Centrica decides not to raise prices so soon after Ed Miliband's speech, and in makes an active decision to forgo profit for PR gains. If British Gas does not make an announcement by mid-November (the IMS is due 14 November) then Centrica would only make a £487m EBIT this year, and this would necessitate earnings per share downgrades, in our view. SSE has a 5% margin aspiration (which we assume will be around 4%, given company commentary) and needs a price rise to keep funds from operations/debt ratio above the 20% target and make consensus of around 120pa share. The company has slightly longer to make an announcement (it has a March 2014 year-end), and retail supply is a smaller activity for SSE. The company's interim results are due on 13 November, and if a price rise does not come then, it is possible prices margins in supply are revised downwards.

It was also a bad week for Serco.

On Monday the outsourcing group began life in the mid-cap index after its eviction from the FTSE 100, and just days later it was faced with a possible investigation by the Serious Fraud Office over electronic monitoring contracts. Both Serco and rival G4S, up 0.5p at 253.9p, have been accused of charging the government for tagging criminals who were either in prison, never tagged at all, or indeed dead.

The Ministry of Justice has already asked the SFO to consider carrying out an investigation into G4S, and now fraud officials have confirmed they are considering information provided by the ministry on Serco. Serco said after the market closed on Thursday it believed it had billed in accordance with the terms of the contract, and was co-operating with the ministry. It said it would not tolerate poor practice and would put it right wherever it was found.

Serco's shares slipped 0.5p to 550.5p, down more than 2% on the week. Analyst Robin Speakman at Shore Capital said:

We believe that investigations and the resolution process are likely to stretch into the first quarter of 2014. Meanwhile, Serco remains unable to effectively participate in the UK government contracting market, in our opinion. We remain cautious on the economic and reputational damage being inflicted [on the company].

Overall, America proved a major influence on shares once more, as confusion over the timing of any cutback to the US Federal Reserve's $85bn a month bond buying programme was heightened by differing comments from various Fed officials. On top of that, investors' nerves were tested by the continuing political impasse over the US budget and lack of agreement over its debt ceiling, as next month's deadline for a possible government shutdown came ever closer.

Meanwhile comments from the Bank of England governor Mark Carney yesterday that he saw no need for further quantitative easing proved another negative for the market. In the eurozone, Germany's government was in the process of being formed after Sunday's elections, while Italy's was struggling to survive, as Silvio Berlusconi's party threatened to quit the fragile coalition.

So the FTSE 100 finished at 6512.66, down 52.93 points on the day and more than 80 points on the week.

Housebuilders were hit by Carney's comments, and the prospect of the Bank taking action to prevent a new housing bubble. Persimmon lost 48p to £10.61, while Taylor Wimpey dropped 3.9p to 97p and Barratt Developments fell 9.6p to 302.1p.

Still with property, estate agency Countrywide closed 26.5p lower at 518p following reports two investors, including private equity group Alchemy Partners had sold £94m worth of shares between them.

Builders merchant Travis Perkins dipped 2p to £16.48 despite Goldman Sachs raising its recommendation from neutral to buy, as part of a selection of companies it said would benefit from an upturn.

But Babcock International bucked the downward trend, adding 8p to £12.01. As it met investors and analysts, the engineering support services group said first half trading had remained positive, and it repeated that full year results would be in line with expectations. Caroline de La Soujeole at Cantor Fitzgerald said:

We are currently expecting adjusted pretax profit of £307m. Consensus is at £312m with the range at £301m-£319m. We remain buyers: Babcock's key markets remain resilient and we are confident there are significant growth opportunities from further outsourcing in both the UK and overseas.

Mining shares were hit as investors avoided riskier assets. Antofagasta lost 23.5p to 830p while Rio Tinto dropped 73.5p to £30.67.

Meanwhile Randgold Resources fell 34p to £45.11 as Bank of America/Merrill Lynch cut its forecast for the gold price by 17% to $1294 an ounce next year, based on a rundown in the Fed's bond buying programme:

Gold prices have stabilised and they could remain supported as the US reaches the debt ceiling. However, we believe the focus of investors remains firmly on a gradual normalisation of US monetary policy. Hence, our base case anticipates sustained headwinds to gold prices. Given the unfolding rebound of global economic growth, we believe the more cyclical precious metals, including silver, are likely to outperform gold.

Among its recommendations it cut Petropavlovsk, down 1.75p to 77p, from buy to neutral "due to significant earnings downgrades and the risk now that they could breach covenants next year." It said:

Petropavlovsk has a covenant of 3.5 times net debt/finance on its bank debt. Under our new gold price assumptions we see the group breaching these covenants in 2014. While this covenant could be renegotiated we see this as another headwind for shares.

Investors continued to bet against Ladbrokes after its Thursday's profit warning, its third this year. The company's shares dipped 2.1p to 171.7p on Friday after dropping 8% the previous day. Ladbrokes blamed most of its problems on delays in it digital division, but analysts said this latest disappointment piled more pressure on chief executive Richard Glynn.

webTitle: 'Inflatable Gay Best Friend' toy elicits Tesco apology

fields.bodyText: Having been obliged to apologise for selling a "Psycho Ward" Halloween fancy dress outfit, condemned for stigmatising those with mental health issues, Tesco might have been expected to scour its website for other potentially offensive items. One, however, was missed. The supermarket giant issued a second apology today/yesterday over the Inflatable Gay Best Friend, a novelty blow-up toy criticised on social media as cheaply stereotypical wuth its figure-hugging pink top and blue shorts. Adding to the concern was that Tesco's website billed the item as the Inflatable G*y Best Friend, using an asterisk in "gay" throughout the listing. "An Inflatable g*y Best Friend @Tesco? What planet you on?" read one tweet. The mystery was soon solved. Tesco explained that the item was offered via its website by another seller, which had put together the listing, complete with asterisks. It was indentified as potentially offensive and blocked before any were sold, but Tesco mistakenly did not remove the page containing the listing. A spokeswoman said: "This product was uploaded to the website by a third-party seller but was removed from sale immediately because we found it offensive. "The webpage should have been removed at that time and we are looking into why it is still visible two months later. We have very clear guidelines for third-party sellers who list items on our website, and are very sorry that on this occasion they weren't followed." The toy is listed on the website as "ready to give you fashion advice, tell you if your bum looks big and bitch about everyone who doesn't wear Jimmy Choos". More oddly it is described as having a "smiling, Gary Lineker-esque face" and supposedly aimed at children aged three and four. It was, briefly, on sale for £5.99. It is still for sale on various other UK websites, including Amazon. Gay rights activists were somewhat less offended than the tweeters, being more dismissive than upset. Ben Summerskill, chief executive of Stonewall, said: "This is like trying to sell ice to Eskimos. We can't imagine why any woman would choose to buy an inflatable gay best friend when there are two million of the real thing already available in modern Britain and most of them are much better looking than Tesco's pale imitation." Peter Tatchell, the veteran campaigner, said it "panders to rather cliched, tired, stereotypes". He added: "I doubt that any offence was intended. It's more a case of an ill-thought-out product brainstorm. "I haven't got a problem with the doll being advertised to three- to four-year-olds, but I wouldn't have thought they would understand the Jimmy Choo and Sex and the City references." On Thursday, Tesco apologised and withdrew its bright orange boilersuit-style "Psycho Ward" fancy dress outfit. Asda has also apologised for selling a "mental patient fancy dress costume", which features someone covered in blood and brandishing a machete. Other retailers have been caught out with novelty toys in the past. Last year, Liberty apologised for selling pastel-coloured wooden toy versions of the Katyusha rocket launcher, the Soviet-made weapon still used by Hezbollah to attack cities in Irsael.

webTitle: Help-to-Buy: George Osborne makes major concession | Heather Stewart

fields.standfirst: Subsidising high LTV mortgages in boom-bust UK housing market was political masterstroke – but economic madness
fields.body:
It's not quite a U-turn on the scale of the pasty tax, or any of the various other elements of the 2012 budget that were subsequently chopped; but George Osborne's decision to allow the Bank of England to carry out an annual review of his flagship Help-to-Buy scheme is a major concession.

The centrepiece of this year's budget, Help to Buy was a political masterstroke, pumping up public confidence just as many potential buyers were thinking about returning to the estate agent's, and helping the government to claim credit for an upswing in the property market that had already been kicked off by the Funding for Lending Scheme.

Economically, however, Help to Buy is madness, as the Treasury select committee, the International Monetary Fund and the outgoing governor of the Bank of England all lined up to say.

Offering taxpayer subsidies for high loan-to-value mortgages worth up to £600,000, just as the incorrigibly boom-bust British housing market is moving from stop-to-go mode, is at best risky, at worst, downright reckless.

Initially, the Treasury's argument was that the scheme would help to spark a building boom, as the surge in demand for homes prompted developers to re-start long-stalled projects.

Housebuilding has picked up modestly – but by common consent it remains well below the levels that would be required to keep prices stable.

Meanwhile, the body left with the hugely difficult and controversial task of pricking a future housing bubble is the new, untested financial policy committee (FPC). Before the FPC has found its feet – and the public have even noticed it exists – it is being forced to contend with a government-backed scheme deliberately aimed at bringing forward up to £130bn in new mortgage lending to risky borrowers who are not being served by the banks.

Most recently, the Treasury's argument has switched from giving developers an incentive to build a rash of new homes, to fixing a specific "market failure" for borrowers with small deposits who are being given short shrift by lenders.

But whatever the current rationale, before Friday's cave-in, Osborne's star signing Mark Carney was facing the prospect of spending the next year fielding relentless questions about whether a housing bubble is inflating, at the same time as the Treasury was pumping out taxpayer-backed loans.

Even now, the FPC will only be allowed to pronounce on the scheme after 12 months; but that must be better than the pretence that subsidising homebuyers is a purely political matter, to be left to the Treasury, while forestalling a crash can be left to the number-crunching technocrats in Threadneedle Street.

webTitle: £3.3bn Royal Mail privatisation pushed through ahead of possible strike

fields.bodyText: The government is racing to push through the £3.3bn privatisation of Royal Mail before postmen and women have the chance to walkout on strike against the "great British flog off". Vince Cable, the business secretary, on Friday announced the coalition will sell up to 70% of the 497-year-old postal service on the stock market on 11 October. The announcement comes on the day that more than 100,000 postal workers begin voting on whether to take days of paralysing strike action. But the result of the ballot will not be known until 16 October with the earliest legal strike date not until 23 October. Billy Hayes, general secretary of the Communication Workers Union (CWU), which represents 115,000 Royal Mail staff, said: "The government continues to press ahead with the sale of the UK postal service despite consistent opposition from the public. "It seems remarkable that the prospectus [for the share sale] is being issued on the same day that postal workers are being sent ballot papers for strike action. Today's announcement changes nothing in terms of the ballot which will go ahead as notified. "Postal workers and the CWU will continue to fight to save services as well as defend their terms and conditions." Formally kicking off the sale, Cable said the government will sell the shares at between 260p and 330p, valuing the business at £2.6bn-£3.3bn. The sale could swell Treasury coffers by more than £2bn. Cable said he had been "encouraged by the interest shown by potential investors so far", which is why the government has increased the amount of shares it may sell from at least 50% to up to 70%. "Today is an important day in the life of Royal Mail: people can now apply to buy shares in this iconic British brand," Cable said. "The sale of government shares will give others a chance to have a real stake in this important company and we are encouraged by the shown by potential investors so far." webTitle: Serco slips after Serious Fraud Office considers investigation into tagging contracts

fields.bodyText: It has not been a particularly good week for outsourcing group Serco. On Monday the company began life in the mid-cap index after its eviction from the FTSE 100, and now it transpires it may be investigated by the Serious Fraud Office over electronic monitoring contracts. Both Serco and rival G4S have been accused of charging the government for tagging criminals who were either in prison, never tagged at all, or dead. The Ministry of Justice has already asked the SFO to consider carrying out an investigation into G4S, and now fraud detectives have confirmed they are considering information provided by the ministry on Serco. Serco said after the market closed on Thursday it believed it had billed in accordance with the terms of the contract, and was co-operating with the ministry. It said it would not tolerate poor practice and would put it right wherever it was found. Serco's shares have dropped 8p or nearly 1.5% to 543p as investors had their first chance to react to Thursday night's statements, but analysts said the news was not unexpected. Robin Speakman at Shore Capital, in a hold note, said: Clearly to our minds, whilst this may be disappointing to investors, it is of little surprise; the SFO being in a much stronger position to review and determine the nature of evidence and actions. Serco are due to present their own internal findings on the contract (and related/ancillary issues) at the end of November. We stress, however, that this is unlikely to coincide with a resolution, in our view. We believe that investigations and the resolution process are likely to stretch into the first quarter of 2014. Meanwhile, Serco remains unable to effectively participate in the UK government contracting market, in our opinion. We remain cautious on the economic and reputational damage being inflicted on Serco - in our view a full resolution remains some months away. Oriel Securities issued a sell recommendation, saying: It looks to us as if the ministry statement is no more than confirming that the processes of SFO investigation, ministry audit of Serco and G4S and wider review by the Cabinet Office of all contracts held by Serco and G4S across government is on-going. Caroline de La Soujeole at Cantor Fitzgerald said the update did not make Serco's position materially worse, but added: If Serco fails to convince the government that it has mended its way it could be frozen from new government work. The UK public sector currently accounts for around 50% of total group sales. Given the cloud of uncertainty hanging over Serco's UK operations, we have a hold recommendation and target price of 550p.

webTitle: FTSE falters on Carney's QE hints but Babcock jumps after positive update

fields.standfirst: Investors react to comments from Bank of England governor about improving UK economy
fields.body:
Leading shares have been hit by new concerns about central bank actions, this time in the UK rather than the US.

But Babcock International is bucking the downward trend, adding 21p to £12.14 and rising to the top of a falling FTSE 100.

Ahead of a meeting with investors and analysts, the engineering support services group said first half trading had remained positive, and it repeated that full year results would be in line with expectations. Caroline de La Soujeole at Cantor Fitzgerald said:

We are currently expecting adjusted pretax profit of £307m. Consensus is at £312m with the range at £301m-£319m. We remain buyers: Babcock's key markets remain resilient and we are confident there are significant growth opportunities from further outsourcing in both the UK and overseas.

Close behind Babcock was Travis Perkins, up 27p at £16.77 after Goldman Sachs raised its recommendation from neutral to buy, as part of a selection of companies it said would benefit from an upturn.

Overall the FTSE 100 has fallen 19.03 points to 6566.56 as Bank of England governor Mark Carney told the Yorkshire Post that an improving economy meant there was no need for further quantitative easing. The markets have been fixated on the US Federal Reserve, and when it would begin to wind down its $85bn a month bond buying programme, and now has the future of the UK's QE programme to fret about.

Investors are also cautious ahead of next month's deadline for US politicians to agree on the country's budget and resolve the issue of raising its debt ceiling. If the impasse remains, the American government could see a shutdown before long. Mike van Dulken, head of research at Accendo Markets, said:

US House Speaker Boehner insists no debt ceiling agreement until spending cuts, which are largely aimed at the Republican dislike of Obama's Healthcare reforms, while the President is standing strong saying will not negotiate. Who'll blink first? Who wants to be to blame for a government shutdown and negative impact on fourth quarter GDP?

After two days of hefty falls in the wake of Labour's pledge to freeze energy prices, Centrica has recovered 2.3p to 369.2p while SSE is up 8p at £14.68.

Miners were among the leading fallers as the appetite for safer stocks returned. Antofagasta has fallen 21p to 832.5p and Rio Tinto is 54.5p lower at £30.86.

webTitle: Final budget figures show smaller deficit than forecast

fields.standfirst: Joe Hockey refuses to make specific commitment about when the Coalition will return the budget to surplus
fields.body:
Final budget figures for 2012-13 record a smaller deficit than the $19.4bn originally forecast in May.

The final budget outcome for 2012-13, released on Friday, recorded an underlying cash deficit of $18.8bn, an improvement of more than half a billion dollars.

The numbers are consistent with Labor's economic statement released in August and the pre-election fiscal outlook released during the election campaign. The improvement in the deficit position was based on higher than forecast company tax and GST collections, lower payments and higher earnings from the Future Fund.

But treasurer Joe Hockey, at a press conference in Canberra on Friday, sought to remind voters of Labor's previous unmet commitment to return the budget to surplus – a promise dumped by then treasurer Wayne Swan late in 2012.

Hockey also warned that the budget position had deteriorated since the August economic statement and pre-election fiscal outlook. He declined to be more specific, saying he would not "speculate" about forecasts ahead of the release of the mid-year economic and fiscal outlook. The government is yet to confirm when that key Treasury forecast will be released, but there is speculation that the document will not be in the public domain until the new year.

Despite campaigning against Labor's failure to return the budget to surplus after the global financial crisis, Hockey also declined to make any specific commitment on Friday about when the Coalition would return the budget to surplus. "You'll see our plan over the next few months," he said.

The treasurer said at Friday's press conference that the new government was going over previous budget estimates line by line. He confirmed that the government would need to pass legislation before Christmas to raise the debt ceiling. "This has to be dealt with and it's Labor's legacy," he said.

He said the first parliamentary sitting week since the election, expected to be in November, would deal with legislation repealing the carbon and mining taxes, abolishing the Clean Energy Finance Council and raising the debt ceiling.

Hockey also pointed to government plans to roll out its list of infrastructure projects, which could be funded in part by raising additional commonwealth debt.

"We are looking at ways we can stimulate growth in the next 18 months and beyond," Hockey said. The treasurer said infrastructure spends based on proper cost-benefit analyses were positive for economic growth.

But the former Labor treasurer Wayne Swan took to Twitter to blast the "pure hypocrisy" of the Coalition's floating of plans to fund new infrastructure via commonwealth debt after being critical of Labor for increasing debt to stimulate the economy.

"After railing against govt-backed debt to fund infrastructure for years, Libs now proposing govt-backed debt to fund infrastructure?" Swan tweeted.

webTitle: Australia's tax mix: examining the case for a rise in GST

fields.standfirst: The main reason for a consumption tax is that even when things are tough, people still keep consuming
fields.body:
Well, it didn’t take long for the issue of the GST to raise its head.

After garnering some early discussion during the election campaign when Kevin Rudd tried to scare the willies out of everyone, the issue mostly stayed out of the way. But as soon as the Western Australian government’s credit rating was downgraded by Standard & Poor’s, the WA premier, Colin Barnett, called for the GST to be increased.

And this week the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development released a paper, Tax Policy Landscape: Five Years after the Crisis, which showed that Australia’s taxation revenue declined much more dramatically than in most OECD nations – primarily because of our high dependency on corporate and income taxes, and low dependency on consumption taxes (the GST).

The report notes that corporate tax revenues “have proven to be the most cyclical of major categories of tax revenue”, while consumption taxes “played a significant part in fiscal consolidation in many countries”.

The Business Council of Australia quickly responded to the report, suggesting it showed the need for Australia to change its tax mix from a high dependency on corporate tax to one more dependent upon consumption taxes.

Now I’ll pause while you recover from the shock of a business lobby group calling for lower company tax rates.

But before we get too cynical about their stance, it is undeniably true that company and income taxes are hit harder by economic downturns than will consumption taxes. The very symptoms of an economic downturn – loss of jobs (and thus income tax) and a drop in the profitability of businesses (and thus company tax) make this so.

This is the main reason for a consumption tax – even when things are tough, people still keep consuming.

It is worth noting, however, that a consumption tax is not the great stabiliser that the above graph would have you believe. The OECD report notes that while consumption taxes did help fiscal consolidation, it came primarily through increases in the tax rates – from 2006 to 2012, 17 of the 34 OECD nations raised their consumption tax rate.

The report also notes that “one of the advantages of increasing [consumption] tax rates, has been that the measure can be implemented rather quickly”. That is not the case in Australia. Yes once the tax rate is increased it can quickly flow through the economy, but the current arrangements of needing all the state and territory governments plus the federal government to sign on suggest it is not a quick fix.

Australia does have a high company tax rate compared with other countries. Our rate of 30% has us as the ninth highest among the 34 in the OECD. But such a comparison ignores that Australia, unlike most countries, has dividend imputation on company tax.

This allows shareholders receiving dividends to claim against their own tax rate. As David Richardson of the Australia Institute noted in his 2012 paper, The Case Against Cutting the Corporate Tax Rate, this “effectively means that the company income is ultimately taxed at just the individual taxpayer’s marginal tax rate”. And when we compare the highest marginal tax rate in the OECD, Australian lands pretty much smack in the middle.

While lowering company tax is often pitched as a way to drive investment, the evidence for such a link is sketchy, especially when looking at driving investment from overseas. The Treasury's Business Tax Working Group did suggest that a lower company tax could lead to increased investment as it lowers a project’s “hurdle rate of return” (ie, the after-tax profit). This in turn could lead to increased capital investment which would “enhance the productivity of labour” resulting in increased economic growth and incomes.

That’s the theory, at least.

Similarly, while the evidence is quite strong that the brunt of increases in company tax falls on workers through declining wages, the evidence of lower company tax rates improving workers' wages is pretty scant. Companies are more likely to use the increase in after-tax profits from a reduced company tax rate to reinvest in the company.

A look at the percentage of Australia’s total factor income that went towards wages and salaries shows that after 2000 when company tax was dropped from 34% to 30%, the percentage of the income going towards wages declined.

It is also worth remembering that the importance of the GST has been declining – as the consumption of items not covered by the tax has relatively increased in the past decade. So a look at the GST, if it is to be about producing more stable tax revenue, really needs to be more about broadening the base than increasing the rate.

But let us not pretend the GST is some wonder tax. As any small business owner would know, it is a bugger of a thing to administer. The Henry tax review was prevented by Wayne Swan from examining the GST, but as the economics blogger Zac Gross noted, the review did actually suggest dumping the GST in favour of a much easier to administer “cash-flow tax”.

The key aspect of such a cash-flow tax, however, is that all consumption is taxed, and I’m not sure if the Abbott government is worried enough about the tax base to take that very politically courageous step.
